Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YENG5581 - Advanced Earth Systems Engineering and Management","description":"

To introduce students to the conceptual and practical challenges arising from the design, operation, and management of earth systems in the context of the anthropogenic earth, characterized by integrated human/natural/built complex adaptive systems at local, regional and global scales. Emphasis will be on characteristics and fundamentals of technology systems; complex adaptive systems behavior and evolution; and associated cultural, ethical, and managerial behaviors, with a focus on the need for multidisciplinary approaches; and current patterns in technological evolution.


This is a fully online course taught by academics from Arizona State University as part of the PLuS Alliance. Among other things this means that a different learning management system may be used and the ASU mark and grade will be converted to a UNSW equivalent. You can find more details about this here.


 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"62413d55db57d850358b403c3a961951","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Consultant Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The required final report of 6000-7000 words (references not counted) will demonstrate a solid grasp and employment of ESEM principles in managing a real-world problem. It will involve significant analysis and make a meaningful contribution to the literature by proposing a plan for managing a wicked problem. Grades will be based on organization, analysis, persuasiveness, flow, proper format, and presentation (e.g., no typos, complete sentences, good grammar).

Attendance and participation in class is mandatory. Meaningful participation in discussion boards and in response to instructor email prompts is expected. Online quizzes will be used to assess attentiveness and will cover readings and lecture material.

In total there will be 12 weeks class attendance and participation, adding up to 24 hours of workload.

Assignments might be returned for rework if quality is poor or if the intent of the prompt was missed. Each missing assignment deducts 5% from final class grade. The focus is on quality content. A minimum acceptable essay will cite at least two sources from peer-reviewed literature or readings assigned for this class. Unless otherwise indicated, essays should be a minimum of 750 words (not counting references).

contentlets.description:
To introduce students to the conceptual and practical challenges arising from the design, operation, and management of earth systems in the context of the anthropogenic earth, characterized by integrated human/natural/built complex adaptive systems at local, regional and global scales. Emphasis will be on characteristics and fundamentals of technology systems; complex adaptive systems behavior and evolution; and associated cultural, ethical, and managerial behaviors, with a focus on the need for multidisciplinary approaches; and current patterns in technological evolution.

This is a fully online course taught by academics from Arizona State University as part of the PLuS Alliance. Among other things this means that a different learning management system may be used and the ASU mark and grade will be converted to a UNSW equivalent. You can find more details about this here.

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YENG5582 - Industrial Ecology, Sustainable Engineering, and Corporate Responsibility","description":"

Industrial Ecology (IE) assumes that industry (human activity) and the environment are tightly coupled, often integrated, co-evolving systems, and thus suggests that industry must increasingly take ownership of and begin to care for the environment. In light of this worthy goal, IE has prompted the development of many tools and methods (e.g., lifecycle assessment, materials flow analysis, etc.) to make it achievable.


This is a fully online course taught by academics from Arizona State University as part of the PLuS Alliance. Among other things this means that a different learning management system may be used and the ASU mark and grade will be converted to a UNSW equivalent. You can find more details about this here.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8d319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961924","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Attendance and participation in class is mandatory. Meaningful participation in discussion boards and in response to instructor email prompts is expected. Online quizzes will be used to assess attentiveness and will cover readings and lecture material.

\n

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"45319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4d319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51319291dbd7d850358b403c3a96192f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written assignments","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

These writing assignments include 6 written essays based on 14 weeks of homework and readings, and are worth 40% of the total course mark and about 80 hours of total workload.

\n

Assignments might be returned for rework if quality is poor or if the intent of the prompt was missed. The focus is on quality content. Graduate level work is expected. Correct grammar, spelling, paragraph structure, citations (in APA format), etc. are expected. Written assignments should be ~700 words (+/-10%) unless otherwise specified.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"45319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"45319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"45319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"4d319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961925","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4d319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961927","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"99319291dbd7d850358b403c3a961932","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Consultant Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The required final report is about 6000-7000 words in length (references not counted) and is worth 40% of the total course mark and about 30 hours of workload. Students will identify, research, analyze, and report on a specific corporate industrial ecology problem. It will involve significant analysis and synthesis. Grades will be based on organization, analysis, persuasiveness, flow, proper format, and presentation (e.g., no typos, complete sentences, good grammar).

Please visit PLuS Alliance website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"YENG5598 - Introduction to Sustainability of Energy Systems","description":"

Energy is critical to the well-being of human society as a whole. Making proper energy choices depends not only on technology, but also on a basic understanding of sustainability science concepts, definitions and general analysis tools. This has to be complemented with some understanding of practical methodologies of evaluating various energy products, conversion pathways and complete energy systems in terms of technical, environmental, social, planning and governance aspects. This course will provide this knowledge through four different sections. The first will cover fundamental and foundational topics related to sustainability in general, with focus on energy systems. The second section will discuss energy consumption patterns, issues related to climate change and human health, and sustainable energy pathways. Next, various aspects and tools developed for analyzing complex and adaptive systems in terms of operational efficiency, resiliency and system dynamics modeling will be covered. Finally, several case studies will be presented to expose the student to current published literature on resiliency and sustainability assessments of energy products, processes and systems. Engineering and science students intending to specialize on sustainable energy would benefit from this course.


This is a fully online course taught by academics from Arizona State University as part of the PLuS Alliance. Among other things this means that a different learning management system may be used and the ASU mark and grade will be converted to a UNSW equivalent. You can find more details about this here.

Assignments might be returned for rework if quality is poor or if the intent of the prompt was missed. The focus is on quality content. Graduate level work is expected. Correct grammar, spelling, paragraph structure, citations (in APA format), etc. are expected. Written assignments should be ~700 words (+/-10%) unless otherwise specified.

contentlets.description:
Energy is critical to the well-being of human society as a whole. Making proper energy choices depends not only on technology, but also on a basic understanding of sustainability science concepts, definitions and general analysis tools. This has to be complemented with some understanding of practical methodologies of evaluating various energy products, conversion pathways and complete energy systems in terms of technical, environmental, social, planning and governance aspects. This course will provide this knowledge through four different sections. The first will cover fundamental and foundational topics related to sustainability in general, with focus on energy systems. The second section will discuss energy consumption patterns, issues related to climate change and human health, and sustainable energy pathways. Next, various aspects and tools developed for analyzing complex and adaptive systems in terms of operational efficiency, resiliency and system dynamics modeling will be covered. Finally, several case studies will be presented to expose the student to current published literature on resiliency and sustainability assessments of energy products, processes and systems. Engineering and science students intending to specialize on sustainable energy would benefit from this course.

This is a fully online course taught by academics from Arizona State University as part of the PLuS Alliance. Among other things this means that a different learning management system may be used and the ASU mark and grade will be converted to a UNSW equivalent. You can find more details about this here.
contentlets.title: Introduction to Sustainability of Energy Systems

The course will introduce a variety of themes including nuclear fission, reactor physics and engineering, the historical context of nuclear engineering, the impact of radiation on matter, fuel fabrication and the fuel cycle, radioactive wastes and storage methods, reactor accidents, and nuclear policy.


The following topics are covered in this class

  • Radiation interactions and dose.
  • Nuclear reaction, fission and fusion theory.
  • Fission reactors, four factor formula, moderation.
  • Nuclear power, TMI, Chernobyl.
  • Nuclear fuel cycle.

The topics are broken into three basic divisions for the term as given below:


I. Nuclear Fundamentals

The following topics are covered in this class


  • Principles of neutron chain reacting systems.
  • Neutron diffusion and moderation.
  • One, two and multi group diffusion equation solution methods.
  • Heterogeneous reactors.
  • Nuclear fuel steady-state performance.
  • Core thermal-hydraulics.
  • Core thermal design.

This course provides students with an introduction to the key elements of reactor physics and thermalhydraulics.


The topics are broken into three basic divisions for the term as given below:


I. Neutron Diffusion


II. Reactor Theory


III. Reactor Design


Students completing this course will be able to discuss aspects of reactor physics and the implications that reactor physics has on the engineering of nuclear systems. Students will be able to perform analyses on simple reactor geometries and describe and understand the main reactivity feedback mechanisms, and their significance, on reactor design and control.


Key concepts such as neutron flux and diffusion are first introduced. These are then utilised to demonstrate multiplication and criticality. The neutron life cycle in thermal reactors is described along with fast and delayed neutron production. Reflected reactors and reactor kinetics are discussed including doubling times, reactivity feedback mechanisms, power and temperature coefficients. The course concludes with a discussion on thermal hydraulics..


A prerequisite for this course is ENGG9741 Introduction to Nuclear Engineering or YENG9741 Nuclear Reactor Theory and Design as the material builds on the physical processes at work during fission including neutron flux, criticality, moderation, reactor dynamics and transients.


This is a fully online course taught by academics from Arizona State University as part of the PLuS Alliance. Among other things this means that a different learning management system may be used and the ASU mark and grade will be converted to a UNSW equivalent. You can find more details about this here.
